I agree with everyone else here that this isn't a good move. DACs are fundamentally super inefficient because you're trying to extract a substance from a mixture where it is diluted to about 400ppb. Industrial mixture separation tends to follow a curve based on dilution and at this dilution you're looking at a theoretical minimum of about $1000 dollars per tonne. Bare in mind current systems are nowhere near that limit and these systems would have to reach that limit to be remotely able to economically compete with other commercial sources of co2. And if these systems aren't looking to be commercially viable then I don't know who they expect to spend billions of dollars removing a fraction of atmospheric co2.

And this is to say nothing about how much these systems emit themselves.

Perhaps in 20-30 years when we have reduced and mitigated all emissions and have an abundant and cheap supply of renewable power this might be a viable choice to reduce damage already done. But at this time this is like trying to bail out the Titanic with a teacup.

And I agree with others that it concerns me when science educator YouTube creators do sponsorships like these where they uncritically support questionable technology. I was disappointed when Mark Rober supported the misguided TeamSeas project too. I expect smart educators to do their homework.

(EDIT, I wrote the following in response to someone else but felt it made some solid points that I needed to share, so there it is below...)
It's the problem of seeing it as 'too much air carbon', rather than seeing it as 'a lack...', because it's really the latter. It clarifies the issue when you realize bringing up topsoil carbon levels solves your air problems, plus you are directly correcting a slew of other problems in one go. Solving for soil carbon makes the issues and answers clearer.

Having increased carbon in the top layer of soil increases water permeability, allowing water to sink in and lessen watershed flooding. It basically acts like sand. It also has the simultaneous ability to retain water, like retains water like clay. It lessens the need for watering/irrigation. It frees up bound nutrients. Reducing fertilizer needs.
Carbon-rich soil is what most of our food crops grow best in. That carbon-rich soil, also called topsoil, also called 'black gold' in the farming/gardening community, etc.

There are also many plusses to building carbon rich soil. It's easy to implement now. Solving for soil carbon also solves related issues involving building food resources, cooling ambient air in summer and reducing the need for cooling tech/electricity pull.
The benefits of building carbon is multipronged. They are well-tested ways that can be done concurrently.
It reduces pollution in a bunch of ways, including CO². It uses solar energy effectively, pennies on the dollar compared to high tech methods (and nature's been using solar and wind power, it's very old tech, lol) to grow the (truly green power) plants need. It's free or relatively cheap. It rebuilds soil nutrients. It builds farm, national and global security. It reclaims land that is currently in cultivation (yes, that's exactly how it's written) because 9f getter land utilization. It lessens the needs for all kinds of chemicals. It prevents the carbon from blowing away and becoming windborne, as well being washed away, plus so much more.

What happens if we ignore soil carbon, and go at high tech solutions; or tepidly solve soil carbon issues? We still have soil carbon issues. We will continue to lose soil carbon. Flooding will still trouble us more than necessary. Farming will still more extractive than restorative of soil and continue to deplete carbon. We'll have decreased food sources. More labor will be required to irrigate; lakes, rivers and ponds will strain to supply needed water while wildlife will . Aquifers will continue to dry out faster than they can replenish.
